title: Judge Rejects Trump’s Bid to Keep Papers Secret in Jan. 6 Inquiry
content: But a Trump lawyer has signaled an intent to appeal the ruling, which raises novel issues about an ex-president’s executive privilege powers.

title: At the Willard and the White House, the Jan. 6 Panel Widens Its Net
content: What went on at a five-star hotel near the White House the day before the riot could be a window into how a Trump-directed plot to upend the election ended in violence at the Capitol.

title: Trump Officials Illegally Campaigned While in Office, Watchdog Finds
content: Mr. Trump’s son-in-law and his chief of staff are among those accused of violating a law designed to prevent federal employees from abusing their power.

title: Inflation spiked in October, sinking Washington’s hopes that price gains would slow down.
content: The Consumer Price Index rose 6.2 percent in October from a year ago, its fastest increase since 1990. That is bad news for President Biden and the central bank.

title: Seeking Global Praise, Boris Johnson Instead Deals With Scandal at Home
content: As the host leader of the U.N. conference on global warming, Mr. Johnson was hoping to project statesmanship. But a mushrooming ethics scandal dominated the week, overshadowing his climate ambitions.

title: Man Sentenced to 41 Months for Assaulting Officer in Capitol Riot
content: The sentence given to Scott Fairlamb, a former New Jersey gym owner, is the most severe so far for any of the more 650 people charged in the Jan. 6 attack.

title: Four Months, 5,000 Miles: A Refugee Puppet Looks for Home
content: In “The Walk,” a 12-foot tall, 9-year-old Syrian girl named Amal trekked from Turkey to Britain to find her mother. In a politically divided continent, were any minds changed?

more_info.byline: By Alex Marshall, Carlotta Gall and Elisabetta Povoledo

title: Padma Lakshmi’s Thanksgiving Turkey: Slow Roasted and Richly Sauced
content: The host of “Taste the Nation” and “Top Chef” isn’t a professional chef herself. That’s why her bird is stress-free and foolproof.

title: The Quiet Scientific Revolution That May Solve Chronic Pain
content: New science is rewriting the book on chronic pain — and may make treatment more accessible

content: As tempting as it is to blame parity, there are other causes for the underdog wins that have shaped the 2021 regular season.

title: The Chip That Could Transform Computing
content: Apple’s custom processors suggest that computers are nowhere near hitting their performance limits.

title: The Skies Parted and My Future Was Decided
content: I had received a calling. I had no choice in the matter. My other interests retreated. I would be a guitarist.

title: If This Country Won’t Listen to Moms, I’m Asking Men to Start Shouting
content: Moms have been telling their stories alone for too long.

content: A controversial new academic start-up throws light on higher education’s long stagnation.

content: But Democrats aren’t helpless.

content: Rikers needs to close. For now, moving people out of there safely and smartly is the bare minimum.

content: Genevieve Guenther and David Wallace-Wells on what matters and doesn’t in your personal fight against climate change.

content: As the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, “an edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring.”

content: Will it show that government can still do big things?

title: ‘How Did We Let People Die This Way?’
content: Thousands of migrants have drowned trying to reach Spain in the past year. This is the story of a man who is committed to returning their bodies home.

title: Can We Have Healthy Conversations Online?
content: Not all online spaces are terrible. Join Shira Ovide, a Times technology writer, for a virtual event on Nov. 18 with the founder of Reddit and a drag queen influencer.

title: Masked Men Attacked a Soccer Player. Her Teammate Is Under Arrest.
content: A Paris St.-Germain women’s player was taken into custody by French investigators looking into a violent assault on a teammate who shares her position.

title: They Wanted to Foster Their Great-Grandson. Why Did New York Say No?
content: A lawsuit challenges New York’s system of disqualifying potential foster parents because of their criminal records.

title: When a Logo Doesn’t Risk It All: Meta’s Brand Is Designed for Unknown Worlds
content: The emblem for Facebook’s new parent company is built for the metaverse, even if it disappoints in the real world.

title: A Communist Leader Was Served Gold-Flecked Steak. The Video of It Has Vanished.
content: A celebrity chef showed the meal in a TikTok video, now removed, that angered people in Vietnam. Facebook said it was investigating why the chef’s hashtag was blocked from its site.

title: China Evergrande meets a Wednesday payment deadline for two of its bonds.
content: Evergrande has three bonds for which grace periods for interest payments are set to expire on Wednesday.

title: U.S. sues Uber, saying it discriminated against people with disabilities.
content: The Justice Department says Uber did not adjust its wait time fees for people with disabilities, even when Uber knew someone needed additional time.

title: A Black Man Killed by a White Mob in 1898 Finally Receives a Funeral
content: The mob killed Joshua Halsey and up to 250 other people that day in the predominately Black city of Wilmington, N.C. Last weekend, city leaders and Mr. Halsey’s living relatives honored him.

title: Tree DNA Sends a Poacher to Prison in 2018 Maple Fire Case
content: Loggers seeking a prized hardwood started the fire in the Olympic National Forest, prosecutors said. The use of timber DNA evidence was a first in a federal criminal trial.

title: Man Arrested Over Fire at Memorial for Pulse Nightclub Victims
content: The man, Mark Henson, 64, was charged with felony criminal mischief after a fire at the memorial, which honors the 49 people killed in the 2016 shooting in Orlando, Fla.

title: Mozambique’s Former Finance Minister Will Face Corruption Charges in U.S.
content: A judge overturned the South African government’s decision to send the minister back to Mozambique, where civil society groups say his political clout will protect him.

title: The Cinderella Myth We Can’t Quit
content: The same woman who stars as the embodiment of poverty in Netflix’s “Maid” is a brand ambassador for one of the world’s largest luxury companies. How very 2021.

title: A Paris Apartment That Spans Styles and Centuries
content: Blending French Empire pieces and more recent ones, the home of the antiquities dealer Jean-Paul Beaujard is as enchanting as the objects he collects and sells.

title: College Basketball Begins With Plenty of Changes
content: There are numerous transfers and players with extra eligibility chasing an N.C.A.A. title.

title: A Biography of E.O. Wilson, the Scientist Who Foresaw Our Troubles
content: In Richard Rhodes’s “Scientist,” a portrait emerges of Wilson’s ability to focus on the smallest details in nature and recognize the ways in which they connect to larger ecosystems.

title: How I Found Comfort in Volunteer Firefighting
content: Facing a world on fire turns out to be a great way not to contemplate one’s own misfortunes.

title: Treating Chronic Pain Takes a Team. I Had to Build My Own.
content: The U.S. health care system can be difficult for anyone to navigate — even more so if you’re a Black woman. So one writer spent a decade building her own care.

content: Working out may seem like the last thing someone in pain wants to do. But it can bring relief.

title: Burning, Crushing, Stabbing: How Words Affect Pain
content: The language you use could make a difference on the pain you feel.

title: How Psychologists Can Help Treat Chronic Pain
content: As doctors and patients worry about the effects of painkillers, therapists are finding they can be a powerful salve for suffering.
